Name: Calgary On Board
Description: Calgary On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in the province of Alberta, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Theatre Calgary and the Calgary Stampede Foundation.

Name: Boulder On Board
Description: Boulder On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Colorado City. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit Impact on Education.

Name: Billings On Board
Description: Billings On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Montana City. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Ronald McDonald House of Billings.

Name: Battle Creek On Board
Description: Battle Creek On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Michigan city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Ouelessebougou-Utah Alliance.

Name: Aurora On Board
Description: Aurora On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Illinois City. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit Cornerstone Mentoring.

Name: Cedar Rapids On Board
Description: Cedar Rapids On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Iowa city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Mercy Medical Center Auxiliary.

Name: Grand Junction On Board
Description: Grand Junction On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Colorado City. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Grand Mesa Youth Soccer Association.

Name: Peterborough and Area On Board
Description: Peterborough and Area On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Ontario, Canada  . Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Peterborough Community Housing Development Corporation.

Name: Danbury On Board
Description: Danbury On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Utah. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area.

Name: Blue Sky On Board
Description: Blue Sky On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Blue Sky Region of Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Almaguin Nipissing Travel Association.

Name: Sault Ste. Marie On Board
Description: Sault Ste. Marie On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the cities in Michigan and Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Algoma University College.

Name: Greater Sudbury In-a-Box
Description: Greater Sudbury In-a-Box is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the North Eastern Ontario Regional Cancer Center.
Families: Series: ... in a Box (Late for the Sky)

Name: North Bay In-a-Box
Description: North Bay In-a-Box is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the North Bay General Hospital – Pediatric Services.
Families: Series: ... in a Box (Late for the Sky)

Name: Lacrosse On Board
Description: Lacrosse On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Wisconsin. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Special Olympics.

Name: Prince Edward Island On Board
Description: Prince Edward Island On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Canadian province. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Junior Achievement of PEI.

Name: Pikes Peak On Board
Description: Pikes Peak On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Colorado. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit Christmas Unlimited, Inc.

Name: Quad Cities On Board
Description: Quad Cities On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the cities of Davenport, Iowa, Moline, Illinois, Rock Island, Illinois, Bettendorf, Iowa, and East Moline, Illinois. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit The Junior League of the Quad Cities .

Name: Racine On Board
Description: Racine On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Wisconsin. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Southeast WI Tri-County Chapter of the American Red Cross.

Name: Regina On Board
Description: Regina On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Saskatchewan, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Friends of the Riders.

Name: Rochester On Board
Description: Rochester On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Minnesota. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Women's Shelter Inc.

Name: Rockford On Board
Description: Rockford On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Illinois. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Comprehensive Community Solutions Inc.

Name: St. Catharines On Board
Description: St. Catharines On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Ontario, Canada . Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Alzheimer Society of Niagara Region.

Name: St. John's On Board
Description: St. John's On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Newfoundland, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Boys and Girls Club.

Name: St. Joseph On Board
Description: St. Joseph On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Missouri. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the America’s Second Harvest of Greater St. Joseph.

Name: Santa Fe On Board
Description: Santa Fe On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in New Mexico. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the St. Vincent Hospital.

Name: Simcoe County On Board
Description: Simcoe County On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the cities in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the United Way of Simcoe County.

Name: Springfield On Board
Description: Springfield On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Missouri. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Leadership Springfield.

Name: The Woodlands On Board
Description: The Woodlands On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Texas. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Rotary Club of the Woodlands.

Name: Timmins On Board
Description: Timmins On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Northern College Foundation.

Name: Topeka On Board
Description: Topeka On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Kansas. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Doorstep Inc.

Name: Tri-Towns and Area On Board
Description: Tri-Towns and Area On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the cities of Haileybury, Cobalt, and New Liskeard in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Temiskaming Art Gallery.

Name: Tulsa On Board
Description: Tulsa On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Oklahoma. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit Leadership Tulsa.

Name: Vaughan On Board
Description: Vaughan On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit The Vaughan Health Care Foundation and The Carole Annibale Ovarian Cancer Foundation.

Name: Windsor On Board
Description: Windsor On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Family Service Windsor-Essex County Foundation   .

Name: Winnipeg On Board
Description: Winnipeg On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Manitoba, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Manitoba Theatre Centre.

Name: Yukon On Board
Description: Yukon On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Yukon territory and its capital, Whitehorse, in Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Yukon Chamber of Commerce.

Name: Kenosha On Board
Description: Kenosha On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Wisconsin. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Southeast WI Tri-County Chapter of the American Red Cross.

Name: Kakuro: The Board Game
Description:
Kakuro: The Boardgame is a one-to-four player game involving of the competitive solving of over 100 Kakuro puzzles. On a given turn, players have sixty seconds to find the solution for a particular section of the puzzle or to challenge an opponent's answer. Once the entire puzzle has been completed (or three players have "timed out" in succession), players consult the solution and score points for each correct answer. The player who filled in the most correct answers wins!

Contained within the box: Instruction book, puzzle booklet, 3D game board, clear plastic overlay, 4 dry erase markers, egg timer, small chamois (for wiping the board between games)

Name: Tic-Tac-Strip
Description: TIC-TAC-STRIP is an exciting adult game of skill and fun, which should be played by four or more. TIC-TAC-STRIP tests your drinking ability as well as your skill in maneuvering your markers in order to jeopardize your opponents. First player to move all four markers from one side of the playing board to the opposite of the board is the winner.

Name: Simply Manners
Description:
This trivia game focuses on good manners, the kind Ms. Manners can truly appreciate.

Sample Question: You have just arrived at a very formal dinner party and are about to go through the receiving line.  You do not know the first person in the line, but you do know the third person.  Who should you approach?

That shows this is a TOUGH game and the 60 minute playing time is a best case scenario for those of us who never graduated from finishing school.

Name: THC The Game
Description: Another treasure from adult game publisher Kheper, THC The Game is designed for people getting high on weed while playing.  Players spin and move around the board, completing dares, articulating challenging tongue twisters, and thumb wrestling.  The dares are determined by players before the game starts and could be taking a shot or taking off a piece of clothing.

Name: Mini-CassiaOpoly
Description: A Pride Distribution fund-raising version of Monopoly celebrating the centennials of Rupert and Burley Idaho.

Name: Battling Space Ships
Description: In Battling Space Ships players draft cards to build space ships - up to three per round. Completed ships can be sent out to carry cargo, attack other players' ships or bases, or attack neutral targets in the space lanes. Points are awarded for successful attacks and for carrying cargo, but completing ships is also worth points and larger ships are worth more. The player with the most points after two rounds wins.

Name: Heibelwijk
Description:
Game subtitle (translated): "Who needs enemies when you got neighbours?!"

Heibelwijk is a game focused on neighbourhood troubles. The occupants of 4 houses are in a constant state of nagging, annoying and badgering each other, to ultimately become the last inhabitant of the game's particular quarter of town.

As a player you have to choose which other player or players (your neighbours) you are going to pester and therefore target, and which neighbour(s) you tactically choose as your very, very best 'friend'. Following the right (social) tactics and strategies are very important in this tiny world of irritation (with an actual irritation board) and friendship. In the end it's up to you to use the commotion, beleaguer, revenge, lucky and disaster cards in the right way.

The game is best played with 4 players, but 2-player rules are included.

Name: Spiderwick Chronicles: The Fantastical Field Guide Mystery Game
Description:
User review: One player plays the goblins by taking one of each opponent. The other players are the Grace children. The Grace children players must get the Dumbwaiter, Key, Trunk, and Field Guide tokens in that order to move on to the second part of the game. The more turns the Grace children take gives the goblin player more opportunities to secure cage tokens to use in the second part of the game.

When the Field Guide has been secured by the Grace children, the children then must get it to Uncle Arthur Spiderwick to win the game. The goblin player wins if the Field Guide can be wrested away from the children and taken to Mulgarath the Ogre.

This game features a 3-D Spiderwick Estate as well as molded plastic goblins. For 2 to 4 players. Ages 8 and up.

Name: Pacific Salvo!
Description: Pacific Salvo! is a stand-alone game module that may be used on its own, or in conjunction with any previously published modules of the system.  Pacific Salvo! contains the basic Salvo! game rules (in the form of the postcard game which includes ten ships, a sheet for 48 ships from World War II Pacific fleets, and a rules folder containing optional rules, scenarios, and Ship Roster.  (From the intro to the game.)

Name: Field of Honour: Jousting
Description: Field of Honour is a simple game depicting a medieval jousting contest.  The standard game is played by two players:  each plays a single knight.  You may thus play the standard game (knight vs. knight), or stage a more elaborate tournament with most any number of players in a single-elimination competition.  (From the intro to the game in Panzer Digest #2.)

Name: Swordfish at Taranto
Description:
Swordfish at Taranto is a solitaire game depicting the British air assault on the Italian port of Taranto in November 1940.  It is a "narrative experience" game, where players set up the game and watch the story unfold before them.  
The object of the game is for the player--playing the British--to gain as many victory points as possible.  
-from the intro to the game in Panzer Digest #2.

The 3rd edition (2021) features a Foreword by Norman Bell, editor of All Guns Blazing of the Naval Wargames Society.

Name: The Evacuation of Königsberg
Description: "The Evacuation of Königsberg" is a 2-player wargame simulating the Russian assault on the East Prussian city of Königsberg and the German defense and evacuation of the city and surrounding areas in early 1945.  While the eventual fall of the city is a foregone conclusion, the goal of the German player is to accumulate victory points by evacuating civilians and military personnel before the fall.  The goal of the Russian player is to prevent this by capturing the city as soon as possible. (From the intro to the game in Panzer Digest #2.)

Name: The 70's: A Game for Your Generation
Description: The 70's is a Monopoly based on the 1970's. Squares are based on historical and cultural trends of the day.

Name: Waukesha County On Board
Description: Waukesha County On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the county in Wisconsin. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Unplanned Pregnancy Connection Inc and Healthy Families of Waukesha County Inc.

Name: Saskatoon On Board
Description: Saskatoon On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Saskatchewan, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Huskies Football.

Name: Schweizer Sport Quiz
Description:
This is a typical trivia game that focuses on sports questions.

There are 7 categories:
(most are focused on the Swiss sports scene)
- Cycling
- Soccer
- Athleticism
- Alpine Sports
- Olympics
- International Sport

You try to move your pawn to the center of the map by answering the questions right. First one to come there wins.
The questions go back to 1924 and up to events in 1992.

Name: Viikinkiseikkailu
Description:
Another game in Peliko's series of games illustrated by Mauri Kunnas.

Very simple spin-and-move fare: Move your ship to the next square matching the color shown on the spinner. The first player to reach the harbor wins. If you land on a special square and lose the challenge there, you have to retreat a few steps.

Name: Hexapawn
Description:
A simple game on a 3x3 grid, where each side has 3 chess pawns. The objective is to get a pawn to the other side of the board, or leave the opponent unable to move. Normal chess rules apply except that the pawns are not allowed a double move from their starting position.

Not really intended as a two-player game, it was designed to demonstrate an artificial intelligence learning technique by using beads in matchboxes. (Old enough to remember matchboxes?) Twenty-four matchboxes were used to represent the possible moves. Essentially, there were two phases. The first phase was to "teach" the matchbox computer to play the game, then a second phase allowed the matchbox computer to play other opponents. The learning speed depended on the skill of the opponent in the teaching phase.

There are variants in which taking the opponent's piece is mandatory ("Dawson's chess") and ones that use larger boards.

Martin Gardner first published this in his Mathematical Games column in March 1962, and subsequently in his book, "The Unexpected Hanging".

Name: Business India
Description:
The follwing has been taken directly from the box (spelling errors have been preserved):

Business India A Trade Game

A game of Buying and Selling Banking Mortaging etc.
Expand your BUSINESS with Tranportation
PROVE YOURSELF AS A RICHER OF ALL

From the Rulebook (written in English and Hindi):

The object of the game is to learn business or trade buying, and selling of properties so that one becomes the wealthiest player by same method and honoured as BUSINESS.  Player come across the game ups and down falls sometimes he gets reward and some times he has to pay penalties etc.  By arriving at CHANCE OR COMMUNITY CHEST.  Right from beginning of the game till the end, it gives to the players excitement, pleasure and ammusement. When a player taken and on a space not already owned, he may buy it from the Bank, otherwise he has to pay rent to the owner of that site, Rents are greatly increased by erection of house and hotels.  During Financial difficulties, properties can be mortgaged to the Bank.

Business India is very similar to Monopoly.

Name: Den ofrivillige spelaren
Description: Every player begins with 1 million. The goal is to have as much money before the time (24 "in game" hour) is out. In the game there is 4 small games you can bet money at - poker, horses, roulette and keno (a sort of lotto).

Name: Femetta
Description: Femetta, a cardgame with a board, where you should collect as many card with the same number as possible, or have as many cards with the same colour as you could. Every third round the points become higher.

Name: Grand Slam
Description: Grand Slam by the Stoll Edwards Company is a card game that can be played by from 2 to 6 players. At the beginning of each hand trumps are selected by cutting the cards. The suits of this game are Stars, Circles, Diamonds and Squares. and each suit has cards numbered from 1 to 13. After the deal the dealer plays a card to the center of the table and each player follows in turn either playing a card of that suit or a trump card or a card of another suit. Highest card in the suit played wins the trick unless a trump is played and then the highest trump card wins the trick.   In this game the first 6 tricks are called 'Par'  which is similar to the first 6 tricks in Bridge being called 'Book' and do not score.  All tricks above 'Par" score 5 points each, A Small Slam (winning 12 tricks scores an additional 50 points while a Grand Slam scores and additional 100 points. Also  each #6 card won adds 5 points, each #10 card won adds 10 points and each #13  card won adds 15 points to your total. Play is to some predetermined number like 500 or 1000 points.

Name: Le Lys et la Cocarde
Description:
Le Lys et la Cocarde is a game about the French Revolution.
Two to six players try to survive the Revolution traveling the gameboard from 1789 to 1799.
110 cards, 2 ten sided dice.

Name: Thorgal: Kolekcjonerska Gra Karciana
Description:
This game is official release, based on comics series: Thorgal (Rosinski/Van Hamme). Graphics are taken from comics, and the whole game is well-kept in original Thorgals climate.

Mechanic:
Each player sends heroes to execute quests. This give him victory points. He who gains a definite number of points - wins. Players may also send heroes and monsters to disturb other players heroes as they try to do their quests.

In the game are these types of cards:
1. Missions - each has level of difficulty, and adds special conditions.
2. Heroes - they are send to finish quests or disturb enemy heroes.
3. Monsters - they can only disturb. Cannot finish quests.
4. Equipment - can be used by heroes.
5. Spells - can by uses only by heroes with spellcasting ability.
6. Special event cards (called in game: ruse) - many different types, and different effects.

Each card can be used as normal card, or can be thrown aside when battle occurs. Thrown cards give bonuses to Attack and Defence.

Name: Home Team Baseball Game
Description: Caption on the box says, "Play by the rules of big league baseball." A 1918 baseball simulation game for 2 players. The game is played on a two level "board." The upper level has the baseball diamond and the lower level has 2 dugouts. The game also comes with spinner. Instructions are on the inside of the lid.

Name: Türkenkrieg (1737-1739)
Description:
Türkenkrieg: The Russo-Austro Turkish War, Balkan Theatre 1737-39
Volume V in the Lace Wars series

TK is a two-player game: Imperial Austria against the Ottoman Empire. The Turks have three provincial armies, composed of a mix of infantry and cavalry, and the Sultan's own army of heavy cavalry, janissaries, and artillery. They can also call upon Wallachian and Tatar allies. The Imperials have their core Habsburg-Austrian army, plus contingents from the Holy Roman Empire, and elements from the personal armies of Saxony, Bavaria, and even Modena. They also have the irregular forces of the Military Border.

Both sides are evenly matched - weakened by war but still dwarfing the forces of their neighbors. The Imperials begin as the aggressors, but will have to play cannily to avoid surrendering the initiative to the Ottomans. Playing for Prestige (like the other games in the series), your goals are modest, but can add up to significant gains that may influence the outcome of the peace talks. The peace process, more or less out of your hands, is the mechanism by which the game ends.

Map scale is 8.5 miles per hex. Unit scale is battalion/regimental. Units are rated for Effectiveness and Movement; raw strength is factored into Effectiveness.

Turns are equivalent to three weeks - 16 turns per year. Each turn is broken down into several phases - supply, operations, admin, etc. There are scenarios for each year of active operations - three in all - and a Campaign Game.

A few key concepts include Initiative and Operational Preparedness, Campaign Plans, Prestige, and Auxiliaries. This game uses the 3rd edition of the Lace Wars rules, amended to 3.1.

The heart of the game is the Operations Phase, where the players move their formations, lay siege to fortresses and engage in battle. The player with the initiative can dictate the pace of the game, but since initiative is based on operational preparedness, it can pass to another side, perhaps at an inconvenient time.

Auxiliary counters represent support troops and irregulars who had a major impact on operations, but cannot be adequately represented as traditional game units. Instead, a player might have a pontooneer auxiliary that he can play onto a stack to help it cross a major river, or a converged grenadier auxiliary that provides a morale bonus in combat. Because of the scale, many combat elements can be used either as units or as Auxiliaries.
[Playing cards could have been used instead of counters, but there are production issues involved, and besides, some of the auxiliaries' functions are hard to indicate with cards. In essence, however, auxiliaries are that kind of game asset, not "pawns" like the combat units.]

Leaders have an important role to play, as befitting an era where personal command was critical. They are rated for skill or effectiveness, personality, and influence (i.e. the chance they have of retaining command despite their incompetence).

The supply system incorporates lines of communication, the strategic placement of depots, foraging, and attrition. River and canal movement has been taken into account and will prove as critical to success as the use of rail lines in games that cover more modern periods.

The combat system has a tactical feel - while not a full sub-system with battlefield maps, it addresses the key issues of frontage, reserves, and supports, as well as firepower and morale. Winning a battle will bring you the acclaim of your noble peers, but may not gain you any strategic advantage; losing a battle can be catastrophic.

Components

1) Eight 12x18 inch full colour maps representing the Danube Basin and the surrounding lands, from the Adriatic to the Black Sea, and from central Hungary to Bulgaria.

2) 1080 counters representing the forces of Austria, Saxony, Bavaria, Hesse, Cologne and other Holy Roman Empire states, Modena, the Sultan's Army, the Ottoman provincial commands of Bosnia, Rumelia, and Silistria, the Wallachians, and the Crimean Tatars.

3) A set of charts and tables, plus several 11x17 inch display cards.

4) A series rulebook - 3rd Edition (3.1) - called the King's Regulations and Orders (KR&Os), a game-exclusive rulebook, scenario & OOB information, and an historical commentary.

Name: Handbook of American Indian Games
Description: This 288-page trade paperback is an very well-researched overview of the sports and games of American Indians.  150 different activities are covered, but of particular importance to board gamers are the chapters on guessing games and ceremonial games.  Most of these are easily recognized as what we now consider party games.

Name: Start Business
Description: Start Business is about the process of starting a business.  Players open shops in different parts of the city of Kiev and then construct roads so that they can place additional shops.  The shops bring income which can be used to buy components (in the form of building blocks) that are used to complete a mission, such as build a school or church.  The first player to fulfill their mission wins.

Name: Wordbattle
Description:
This is a word game that can be played with any number of players.

It is composed of three dice with letters and one die with numbers - there are four letters or numbers with their own color on each side of the die.

Once the dice are rolled, in the allotted time (3 minutes), players try to make a word with the twelve visible letters . Points are given with each letter of the word receiving the value of its like-colored number. In addition to basic 3-6 letter words, the scorecard rewards bonuses if the player can come up with an animal, a name of a town, a word that is 7+ letters, and a word that is composed solely of one color.

A game lasts eight rolls of the dice, with one category on the scorecard being completed with each roll. The player with the highest score at the end wins.

Name: Rich Man, Poor Man, Beggarman, Thief
Description:
Starting as "beggarmen," players circle the board working their way up the ladder of success.  Beggars can get "charity" from non-beggars, rich men and poor men collect regular incomes, and thieves can steal from rich and poor alike.  There's fast money to be made through investments and playing the horses, and faster money through gambling on a dice throw--but developing real estate is safer.  The many options and sudden changes of fortune make this an exciting, free-wheeling game.

(Description from Nov. 1985 issue of GAMES Magazine, p. 45)

Name: Plasma Duel
Description:
Use warriors, dragons, catapults and cards to conquer and destroy opponent and win Plasma Duel.

This is a miniatures game included with Mega Bloks' Plasma Dragons construction toy line (a Canadian LEGO compatible toy).  Players' soldiers pair off and fight using random draws from pre-constructed decks, plus players can use rubberband-powered catapults to try to hit enemy soldiers without resorting to hand-to-hand combat.  Players can include dragons in their armies, which cost more but tend to have more powerful combat draws.  The loser of each battle loses a piece, until all pieces from one army have been eliminated.  Last man standing wins!

Name: Wallace's War
Description:
(from Clash of Arms:)

Centered in the Scottish Wars of Independence, William Wallace, the Brave Heart of legend, faces the real task of defeating the English on the medieval battlefield.

His greatest victory; Stirling Bridge, 11 September 1297, pits him and the Scottish rebels against the larger, professional English army of the Earl of Surrey. Luring the English across the bridge, Wallace and Moray strike hard when only half the English had crossed. Three scenarios explore the historical situation.

His greatest defeat; Falkirk, 22 July 1298, once again pits Wallace, now the Guardian of Scotland, against the English, led by Edward I (Longshenks) himself. Falkirk would be a great English victory but at the cost of much blood...and would herald the age of the long bow in English history.

Based on the Baron's War system, Wallace's War focuses on the command and weaponry of the medieval battlefield.



(from the Designer:)Wallace's War is the second game in the medieval game series (the other is Barons' War: The Battle of Lewes and Evesham) and this time focuses on William Wallace and his two major battles, Stirling Bridge and Falkirk. The system has been cleaned up considerably by Frank Hastege (who did yeoman's work on the rules). The goal of the series is to create a platform on which to re-create the medieval battlefield. The system is meant to reflect the problems that leaders of the time had. One special focus is the control one has on the battlefield. Once the battle started the leader had the problem of how to change his initial plan if things started to go poorly.

Name: Cuckoo, A Society Game
Description:
A card game from the J.H. Singer Company of New York , copyrighted 1891. Each player is provided with a card which he or she must place in front of themselves on the table in plain view of all, he or she is also provided with 9 counters. The players throw a die in turn and the color thrown must be covered on the card by a counter. The die is six-sided die with 2 sides green, 2 sides red, 1 side white and 1 side black. If "black" is thrown the players must take a counter off of his/her card, if he should have none to take he/she loses the next turn.

The player who first succeeds in covering all of the spaces on his/her card calls out CUCKOO and wins the game.

Name: The Princess and the Pea Game
Description: A children's game for ages 5 and up.  From the publisher's catalog: "Just like Hans Christian Anderson's beloved fairy tale The Princess and the Pea the prince is searching for a real princess.  In this game, you move your bed along the board, adding mattresses to it as you go.  To win, you need to build the highest bed and reach the special "crown" space!  Are you the real princess?"

Name: En-Ar-Co Automobile Tour
Description:
Actually a spin and move game for from 1 to 4 players. The game En-Ar-Co Automobile Tour was developed by EN-AR-CO Brands of Scientific Refining and produced by the National Refining Company in 1919. Each player spins to see who will go first. Players then spin in rotation, each player taking one turn. You then move a number of circles equal to the number that you spun. If the dial of the spinner lands exactly on a line you take another turn. If more than one auto lands on a circle they both stay there. Some circles give players one or more extra spins while at some other points you must go back a certain number of circles. If a player lands on the last circle located at number 45 before entering the large final circle, he must spin a #1 in order to win the game.

See Also:

     En-Ar-Co Auto Game A similar 1925 game also issued by En-Ar-Co, with a different track.

Name: Fast Car
Description:
"Enjoy the thrills and action of stock car racing in this exciting board game. Race on either of the 2 tracks with as many as 8 racers"

Roll & move racer with a NASCAR flavor but without a NASCAR license. Board is double-sided with a standard oval track on one side and a road course on the other.

Roll & move mechanic is modified by "Lap Cards" and "Track Cards." Track cards [denoted by icons on the board] present move bonuses or penalties.

Drawn as a driver completes a lap, Lap Cards give drivers various numbers of points, instruct drivers whether or not to pit, or present drivers the opportunity to send an opponent to the pits.

Name: Gee Wiz Racing Game
Description:
This game features a fly wheel and a starting grid for 6 horses. From the rules: Before running the race be certain that all horses are lined up evenly at the barrier (starting point) and that all the flags at the opposite end of the track are lowered. To operate, hook loop in string over the pin in the shaft and wind by turning the fly wheel away from you 5 or 6 times. Then hold the game down with one hand and give a vigorous pull toward you. This should keep the fly wheel spinning with enough power to carry all of the horses the complete length of the track to the point where the flags go up. As the horses finish the flags rise, for instance if the white flag goes up then the white horse has won the race and the flags go up in corresponding sequence as the horses all "come in".  To line up the horses for the next race simply pass the string in front of the horses and draw them back to the start line. All horses have an equal chance of winning the race because once the race starts no one can have control of the action of the horses.

The rules then go on to say that in some instances dirt or dust can retard the forward motion of a horse. To avoid this,  the grooves in the tracks should be kept clean by occasional use of a soft cloth. Also a drop of lubricating oil on the bearing at each end of the fly wheel now and then is advisable and that GEE-WHIZ should be played on an even and level surface.

Name: Zwerge
Description:
This is another charming key-chain game from Haba. An unusual feature of this range of games is that the name of the game that appears on the packaging (and only the back of the packaging) is different from the name of the game in the rulebook. So while this game might be labeled as Zwerge, the rules call it Schneewitten und die sieben Zwerge (Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs).

Described as a cheeky die game for 2 dwarfs aged 4-99, the authors are Wolfgang Dirscherl (who has designed several games in this series) and Markus Nikisch. The illustrations are by Stefan Fischer.

You get 7 wooden dwarfs in 3 colours (divided 3-2-2), and a special die with spots of the 3 colours (the colour with 3 dwarfs is repeated), a side showing Snow White and a side showing the wicked witch. Players take turns rolling the die. If the die shows a coloured spot, the player takes a dwarf of that colour from the centre, or from the other player if there aren't any more of that colour in the centre. If the die shows Snow White, the player gets to take a dwarf of any colour from the centre or the other player. If the die shows the wicked witch, the player nominates a colour and both players return all dwarfs of that colour to the centre. The game ends when there are no more dwarfs in the centre and the player with the most dwarfs wins.

Name: Familjekampen
Description: Action boardgame containing the four "non-Olympic" contests Pieshot, Biscuitdribble, Closething, and Apegymnastics.

Name: NFL Strategy Jr.
Description: Produced in 1974 with new NFL rule changes, this is a version of the NFL Strategy game for younger children. This game is a generic simulation of American football. (No real teams or players) Each turn the offensive player chooses a run or pass play from a set of cards while the defensive player chooses from 4 run defenses and 4 pass defenses by placing pegs into a hidden matrix. The offensive play is then inserted into the defensive matrix and 5 possible results are revealed. A die is then rolled and the color of the die face indicates which play result to use. Regular football rules are used, such as 4 downs to gain 10 yards, and scoring is the same as in the real game. As in real football, the object of the game is to outscore the opponent.

Name: Sternsammler
Description: Help a poor, little girl collect "pennies from heaven."  Roll the dice and move the girl around the board.  If she stops under a star gate drop a penny and pick it up.  Whoever has the most pennies at the end of the game wins.

Name: Wealth
Description:
From the publisher's site:
"Wealth has little to do with luck or chance. But as in life, its accumulation is the result of the choices you make or take. Educational, Captivating & Fun! Choose your strategy carefully & you will capture wealth."

When rolling a die for movement and potential earning, players may also roll a "words die" that has consequences such as "Super Opportunity," time to use the spinner or draw a card; "Second chance," "Obstacle," and "Fail," which directly affect moving forward, back, or at all; "Break Even," which lets you move without earning; and "Modest reward," giving the player a choice for movement.

You win by going around the non-square board twice, avoiding taxes and buying and selling property.

US Patent number 7275745.

Name: USA Trucking
Description:
"The object of the game is to go around the board and go up your Truck Terminal to the Central Trucking Terminal to eliminate your opponents without going bankrupt. If at any time during the game a player goes bankrupt that player is out of the game.

Real trucker situations and scenarios during game play make this a must have for truckers and
non-truckers alike!"

Name: Paree Mutu-el Race-Trak
Description:
Rules from AGPC Archives: The game is played with a deck of Horse Cards with names of horses and numbers 1 to 3 printed on each card. 5 horses are entered in a race (hand), a horse can finish 1st, 2nd, or 3rd. During the race (hand)all players try to form a sequence of horse cards from 1 to 3 in front of them. Beginning with number 1 and then adding 2 and 3 consecutively. A player completing the sequence 1-2-3 ends the hand (race). The winning sequence does not have to be completed with the same horse in all three positions. If a  player does complete the 1-2-3 with the same horse that player becomes the next BANKER. The banker in the game sells and redeems Bank shares and Wager Tickets. All money received from the sale of bank shares and wager tickets is kept in an account. At the end of the game the amount in this account is divided among shareholders with an equal amount being given for each share held. At the beginning of the game players can purchase bank shares which are always redeemable for their face value. Anyone not redeeming purchased bank shares during the game is entitled to a split of whatever money is in the bank at the end of the game. At the beginning of the game (race) players can purchase wager tickets on their favorite horses. Bets are made across the board in all 3 positions and players collect from the bank for how a horse finished.

In order to play the game the deck of cards is shuffled and then the first player draws a card, if its a number 1 card it is kept face up in front of the player, if its any other card it is discarded play continues until someone has completed the 1 2 3 sequence at which time players holding winning tickets matching names of horses somewhere in the winning sequence are paid off. In other words when the wining sequence happens if you had bet on horse 'Stewball' to finish second on one of your betting cards and the winning sequence actually has 'Stewball' in the #2 position that wage ticket wins money for you.

Name: Edgar Bergen & Charlie McCarthy's Game of Topper
Description:
Edgar Bergen's and Charlie McCarthy's Game of Topper has 8 wooden Toppers, one deck of 36 special playing cards, a score pad and a playing board. The number of toppers used in the game is always one less than the number of players playing. the deck is made up of 36 cards in books of 4 cards each. A book consists of 4 cards having the same number. As many books are used as number of players in the game, so if you only have 6 players your starting deck would d have only 24 cards (6 books of 4).
How to play. The dealer places the toppers on the playing board in the center of the table. He then shuffles and distributes the card face down to everyone. The object of the game is to get a complete book of cards in their hand. You do this by passing one card to the player on his left. That player decides if he wants to keep the card and give a different card or if he wants to pass the card on to the next player. This goes on until a player has 4 cards the same in his hand at which time that player then grabs a topper from the center of the board and then everyone else tries to make a mad grab for a remaining toppers. Of course since there is always one topper less than the number of players playing one will not get a topper. that player accumulates the letter T on his score card. Each additional time that the player gets no topper another letter in the word TOPPER is accumulated. The first player who has TOPPER next to his name loses the round and sits out the rest of the game which is then played with less cards and less toppers. Eventually only one player remains and he wins the game.

Name: Mjölk är livet
Description:
Mjölk är livet (English, Milk is life) is a Swedish game about milk and dairy production.

Each player starts out as a farmer and tries to take as good care as possible of his cows, in order to increase their milk production. Later on each player opens his own dairy and refines the milk into different dairy products. The first player to fill his production quota wins the game.

Name: 5150: Illegal Aliens
Description:
This is an expansion for the base game 5150.

From the publisher's website:

This book will introduce you to eight new aliens. Inside ILLEGAL ALIENS you will find complete descriptions for each of these alien races. These include pictures and the following information:


     Who these aliens are.
     Their current history.
     The type of Encounters they have.
     Their Prime Motivator.
     Their small unit organization.
     The Attributes they possess including new ones not previously mentioned in 5150.
     The weapons they use at squad level.
     Any available support weapons.
     What reinforcements are available.
     What type of vehicles they can utilize.
     And finally complete stats for their weapons.


In addition we have included one scenario that introduces yet another new alien for a total of nine! This scenario features a new alien known simply as the "Night Terror".

So without further adieu, let us introduce you to your new neighbors!

Name: 5150: Infestation
Description:
This is an expansion for the base game 5150.

From the publisher's website:

Infestation introduces the “tactical role-playing game” side of 5150. Players can use Infestation to “flesh out” their characters, giving them an almost life-like feel. Infestation blends the traditional RPG with fast and easy to follow combat on a personal level. Combining these two aspects allows players to enjoy the cinematic aspect of role-playing while keeping the excitement of a miniatures wargame.

Infestation covers...


     Fast movement
     Firing while fast moving
     The H'DAN CORPORATION flash-bang grenade
     New grenade throwing procedures
     Explosions in confined spaces
     Delayed explosions
     New ranged combat chart
     Specific hit locations and damage
     Cover handled in a different way
     Variable damage to figures
     New melee system
     Man Down check
     Computers and hacking
     New equipment
     Encumbrance
     Psionics with new QRS
     "Half Deads"
     Complete scenario that introduces new movement system
     New "in encounter" encounter system
     New variable time clock for encounters
     Covert Operations Group with new QRS
     Covert operations
     Security robot - with new QRS HAFER-2 Security Bot
     Xeogs are refreshed to use in the scenario if needed - with QRS
     New way to play solitaire or same side two new aliens with QRS

Name: Supervillain University
Description:
(From the publisher's website):

Supervillain University is a disturbingly fun card game from Alleged Enterprises for up to 6 players. In it, you take on the role of a senior at SVU, bent on completing a series of Secret Agendas that will be culmination of all your hard work and launch you into the world as a card-carrying Junior Supervillain In Training. The only problem? You have a bunch of classmates (read: enemies) who are hell-bent on stopping you and beating you at your own game. With elements of resource-gathering, roleplaying and fast-paced screwing over of all those who oppose you, there’s truly something for everyone. Provided, of course, that “everyone” enjoys backstabbing, conniving and The Wrong.

There are two main phases to the game. In the resource-gathering phase, one player (the rotating TA) reveals an Opportunity that might present itself on a typical day at Supervillain University. All other players will quickly respond, in secret, with their chosen Evil Deed. The TA collects these played actions, reveals them and determines (based on whatever utterly subjective criteria he or she deems fit) which one is the winner. The player with the winning Evil Deed for the round now collects critical resources needed to complete the all-important Secret Agenda in Phase Two.

After collecting sufficient resources, a player may reveal their Secret Agenda – a truly nefarious scheme guaranteed to bring the world to its knees. If the player can survive a flurry of attempts by the other players to sabotage their Secret Agenda, he or she will collect valuable "points." After collecting an arbitrary number of "points," the winning player may then lord his or her mastery over the other losers playing the game.

Name: Casino Millennium Millionaire
Description:
Players take turns to roll the dice and move round a track on the edge of the board. The space they land on allows them to play different casino games, betting their in game money on the outcome.

Players whose turn it is not are kept engaged by being allowed to place side bets on the players whose turn it is, after paying the player whose turn it is a small fee for the privilege.

Winner is the player with the most money at the agreed end of the game, usually a certain time or amount of money.

The Game Consists of: 
Casino Millennium Millionaire board 
Casino Millennium Millionaire cards 
Pack playing cards for Blackjack 
Set of Poker dice 
Set of Pokies dice 
Dice 
Playing Tokens 
Paper money: 20 x $500, 50 x $100, 50 x $50, 50 x $20, 50 x $10, 
Casino Chips: 30 x $100 (Red), 20 x $500 (Yellow)

Name: Walsingham
Description:
The late 1500s. Spying in Elizabethan times. The instability brought about by the Reformation and Counter-Reformation racks Europe, as does the looming Ottoman threat. This is a time of intrigue and international espionage on a grand scale. A game of the shifting tides of faith and indirect confrontation.

The Players represent 2-5 powers: England, Spain, France, Holy Roman Empire, and the Ottomans.

Each player has a set of action cards (Espionage Cards) to use each turn, which are used to increase or decrease faith, as well as lobby for influence with certain power centers (e.g., the Vatican, the Hanse). These are put within a "sealed envelopes". Players simultaneously reveal their actions.

THE BOARD: MEDITERRANEAN
Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East, all broken into "Provinces". Each “Province” has advantages to certain players, marked by its initial religious affiliations: Protestant, Catholic, Orthodox, Moslem. These Provinces form Meta-Regions (Britain, Germany, Balkans, etc.).

THE BOARD: POWER CENTERS
Twelve slots and a city name next to each slot. The Power Player cards and stacks will be placed onto this board.

Name: Doctor Snuggles uppfinning
Description:
This is a childrens game Ages 4 and up.

Each player receives an amount of cards, you have to lay them down   by following the colors. The player who ends up with no cards first is the winner of this game.

Contents:
1 board game
24 tiles

Name: Smurfspelet
Description:
Free Smurfan from Gargamels nest. Before enter Gargamels house you need to collect gammelsmurfen, the magic potion and the puppet. Your journey will take you through the forest. But be aware about Gargamels cat Azrael who will try to catch you.

Content:

    1 board game
    24 cards
    4 playing counter
    7 surprise cards
    dice
    rules

Name: Word Rigger
Description:
This is a version of Boggle played with cards.  Each player is dealt 10 cards, then has three minutes to make as many words with their hand of cards as they can.  Like Scrabble, each letter has a point score associated with it, so that each word can be scored.  The game has 4 levels of difficulty.  At higher levels, players get larger hands of cards, and their words must have more letters in order to score.

The game comes with rules in English & Spanish, the deck of cards, and a sand timer.

Name: Harrow
Description:
From the Paizo website:
Divine your future! Lose your shirt! All in one box!

In the Pathfinder Chronicles campaign setting, the Harrow deck has long been a sacred tool of Varisian fortunetellers. In skilled hands, the Harrow deck can predict crop results, divine the gender of your unborn child, or give hints about your immediate future. In unskilled hands, the Harrow deck is a sacrilegious gambling game—a cutthroat diversion for ruffians in every port to lose their hard-earned fortunes.

Harrow will be featured throughout the second Pathfinder Adventure Path, Curse of the Crimson Throne. At least once in each installment, players may divine their futures with the Harrow deck, and Pathfinder #7 contains an in-depth article about the history of Harrow and its in-game use.

Harrow is also a standalone card game designed by Jason Bulmahn, Mike Selinker, and Teeuwynn Woodruff for use inside or outside the Pathfinder Chronicles campaign setting. Harrow is lavishly illustrated by Kyle Hunter, the artist behind Downer: Wandering Monster and Downer: Fool's Errand, the Paizo Comics compilations of Kyle's original Downer comics from Dungeon magazine.

This item also has an entry on RPGG: Harrow Deck

Name: Crazy Tennis
Description:
This game is a tennis simulation that can be played by 2 or 4 players. The goal is to exhaust your opponent without getting too tired yourself. Moving and shooting the ball costs energy points, if you get to 0, you loose the point.

Two modes are permitted by the game, simulation or crazy. The first one corresponds to a classic tennis match, the second one adds special, non-realistic moves.

This is do it yourself game, that can be downloaded for free on the author's website.

Name: Roundtable Games
Description:
Roundtable Games consists of four different 2 - 4 player games that are designed to be played on a common game board, called the Roundtable. The four games are Roundtable Chess, Roundtable Checkers, Wordstack, and Checkers Roulette. The game includes 4 complete sets of chess men, 4 complete sets of checkers (15  per set), and four sets of letter tiles (45 per set) that are used for playing Wordstack and Checkers Roulette.


     Roundtable Chess is extreme and exciting chess play for 2 or 4 players. Each player plays with a complete set of 16 chessmen. Chessmen move and make captures as done in the traditional two player chess game. Chessmen in Roundtable chess can also be move in circular directions. Each player’s objective is to gain control of the center of the Roundtable by safely moving his/her king into that position without it being checked or captured. The first king to control the center of the Roundtable wins.
     Roundtable Checkers gives traditional checkers and extreme twist of excitement and face lift. It's designed for 2 or 4 players. Each starts with 15 checkers and can choose thousands of ways to set them up.  Players can also move up to four different checkers per turn in a circular, diagonal, horizontal, or vertical direction. Like regular checkers, you make single or multiple jumps to capture the opponents' playing pieces. The player that captures the greatest number of enemy checkers wins.  
     Wordstack is an exciting 3-dimensional word game that plays 2 or 4 players. Each player selects 15 lettered checkers from her set of 45 tiles ranging from A to Z. Players may move up to 10 different lettered checkers per turn in diagonal, vertical, horizontal, or circular patterns. The player's objective is to earn points by combining (joining) her checker(s) with an opponent's checker(s) in order to spell words. Words may be spelled forward or backward, and in a diagonal, vertical, horizontal, or circular direction. Players may also capture (jump) an opponent's checker(s) to form a stack of checkers. The stack of captured checkers becomes a "Wordstack" when it is combined (joined) with an opponent's piece(s) to form words. The player who earns the highest number of points wins.
     Checkers Roulette is numbers fun for 2 or 4 players. Each player uses 15 numbered checkers that include the values 5, 10, 25, and 50.  Players may move up to 4 different checkers per turn in a circular, diagonal, horizontal, or vertical direction. You score points by capturing (jumping) an opponent's checker(s), and lose points when your checkers are captured. For example, if your checker with the value of "5" captures an opponent’s checker with the value "10", you earn 50 points (5 × 10 = 50), and the opponent loses 50 points. You also earn or lose points by setting up plays. The player that earns the greatest number of points wins.

Name: Hostile Takeover: The Game of Wealth, Power and Insider Trading
Description:
From the Designer:

The Wall Street takeover movement has come home!  Hostile Takeover lets you become a corporate industrialist building and raiding billion dollar fortunes.  Develop your own strategy.  Start a bidding war.  But watch out for other players' ambitious plans, changes in the stock market, cash crunches, and insider trading scandals.

Hostile Takeover is exciting, easy to learn, and educational.  Learn firsthand what those Wall Street contenders have known for a long time.

Greed is Fun!

Game Contents includes:
1 - Playing board
30 - Company Cards
16 - Bulls, Bears and Pigs cards
13 - Inside Information Cards
12 - Random Walk Cards
1 - Tally Sheet Pad
1 - Record Sheet Pad
1 - Bid Summary Card
Color Coordinated Ownership Marker in four colors
Color Coordinated Bid Markers in four colors
Congolmerate Group Markers
Dice
Millions and Billions in play money
Financial Terms Glossary
Industry / Company Index

Name: Dogs of War
Description:
Players build teams of Mercenaries (Mercs) and send them on missions.

The player with the most money at the end of the game wins. Players can keep their money hidden from each other.

Roll high on 1D6 to determine turn order.
Each player starts with $100,000.
Shuffle the deck.
Each player is dealt 7 cards.

The game ends when a player goes to draw a card from the deck, and there are no cards left.

Name: Boom Town
Description:
Players are rival Business Bosses in an old west boomtown. 
Hire Gunslingers to do your Dirty Work.
The first player to acquire $100 becomes the new Mayor.
A complete copy of the rules is available for free.

Name: Gremlins: The Game
Description:
Gremlins: The Game is a simple, fast game for 2-4 players ages 8 & up. Each player travels around Kingston Falls trying to eliminate Stripe and the Gremlins besieging the town.

The game board depicts the different locations in town, such as Dorry’s Tavern, the Peltzer Home, and the Department Store. Each location in the town is connected by a series of game spaces. Hidden throughout the town are little Gremlins represented by face down cardboard tiles. Players move around town trying to find weapons they can use to eliminate the Gremlins, such as Snack Trays, Microwave Ovens, and Ornamental Wall Swords.

And yes, you can blow up the Movie Theater and everything inside it!

Name: Spanish Fury, Siege!
Description:
This gamette (actually a full game on it's own) will allow you to play out a siege of a Sixteenth century Town or Fortress from the pounding of the first spade into the earth to the capture of the town square!
Included are two maps, one of a town on a river and one of a coastal port, counters for companies of Foot, Horse, Pioneers and Cannon, and a complete generation system for creating your own scenarios quickly and easily.

Name: Pyramid Cards
Description: This is a bidding and trick-taking card game.  The deck has 5 suits numbered 2 through 12, along with 2 wild cards.  It's unusual in that there are rules for playing in 2 or 3 partnerships, like Bridge, along with rules for playing as singles, like Hearts.  Along with the deck, the game was sold with a big score pad.
